unnormalised: ## Lights, Camera, Festival! Your Guide to the Film Fest Circuit
normalised: ## Lights, Camera, Festival! Your Guide to the Film Fest Circuit

unnormalised: Hey Bollywood buffs and indie film lovers! Ever dreamt of rubbing shoulders with filmmakers and watching movies that haven't even hit theaters yet? Then you gotta check out the film festival scene!
normalised: Hey Bollywood buffs and indie film lovers! Ever dreamt of rubbing shoulders with filmmakers and watching movies that haven't even hit theaters yet? Then you gotta check out the film festival scene!

unnormalised: Think of film festivals as massive parties celebrating the art of cinema. They're not just for industry bigwigs; they're super accessible for anyone passionate about movies. We're talking everything from small, community-based fests to internationally renowned events.
normalised: Think of film festivals as massive parties celebrating the art of cinema. They're not just for industry bigwigs; they're super accessible for anyone passionate about movies. We're talking everything from small, community-based fests to internationally renowned events.

unnormalised: India’s own International Film Festival of India (IFFI) in Goa is a big one, of course. But there are tons more. The Mumbai Film Festival (MAMI) is fantastic, too, attracting a great mix of international and local talent. These fests screen everything from hard-hitting documentaries to quirky short films, and even the occasional blockbuster-in-the-making. Remember that buzz around "Gully Boy" at the Berlin Film Festival before it became a national hit? That’s the kind of magic that can happen!

unnormalised: But even smaller festivals, like the Kolkata International Film Festival, or some of the regional film fests in, say, Chennai, are worth a visit. They offer a glimpse into unique regional cinema you wouldn't typically find in your local multiplex.
normalised: But even smaller festivals, like the Kolkata International Film Festival, or some of the regional film fests in, say, Chennai, are worth a visit. They offer a glimpse into unique regional cinema you wouldn't typically find in your local multiplex.

unnormalised: So why should you bother? Well, for starters, you get to see films way before your friends! Plus, you get to participate in Q&As with directors, attend workshops, and generally geek out with fellow movie enthusiasts. The networking opportunities alone are worth the price of admission (usually a reasonable Rs. 500- Rs. 2000, depending on the festival). And hey, you might even spot Shah Rukh Khan chilling in the lobby! (Okay, maybe).

And hey, you might even spot Shah Rukh Khan chilling in the lobby! (Okay, maybe).

unnormalised: Tips for navigating a film festival? Plan your schedule! With so many screenings happening simultaneously, you don't want to miss that indie gem everyone's talking about. Pack comfortable shoes – you’ll be walking a lot! (Especially if you're travelling from Delhi and not used to Mumbai's humid climate). And most importantly, be open to discovering something new. Who knows, you might stumble upon your new favorite filmmaker! Happy viewing, folks! Now, if you'll excuse me, I'm off to research film festivals within a 100 km radius of Pune.
